organization: House of Representative Committe on Small Business
ask: "As the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA or the Agency) works to issue a final rule for these commodities, I urge the Agency to ensure that small businesses are not burdened with unnecessary record keeping requirements."
ask1: "The Agency should seek to be as flexible as possible in permitting existing records kept by small businesses in the food industry to satisfy the recordkeeping requirements of mandatory country of origin labeling"
ask2: "Additionally, the Agency should be flexible when it comes to where the records must be maintained."
ask3: "Small businesses should also be given a reasonable amount of time to respond to requests for records by the Agency."
notes: Link to proposed rule: https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2003/10/30/03-27249/mandatory-country-of-origin-labeling-of-beef-lamb-pork-fish-perishable-agricultural-commodities-and , link to actual rule: https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-7/subtitle-B/chapter-I/subchapter-C/part-65  ... Comment from Cynthia Rendeiro
ask: I support a regulatory change that would require licensees to regularly demonstrate compliance with the Animal Welfare Act before renewing their license or significantly expanding their operations.
ask1: I also support required disclosure of animal cruelty violations.
response: APHIS will phase in the transition of licensees from 1-year to 3-year terms. Approximately 1/3 of current licensees will be transitioned each year, beginning in 2021

title: Comment from Andy Treharne
ask: CSF appreciates the opportunity to support delisting of Brucella abortus from the list of select agents.
response: Brucella abortus: This agent presents little economic or animal health risk as it is unlikely to result in large-scale population introduction due to the high concentration of the agent necessary to produce disease as well as modern cattle production processes that limit animal-to-animal transmission routes. There is an efficacious vaccine, moderate immunity status within vulnerable populations, limited farm-to-farm transmission risk, and effective quarantine procedures.
accept_phrases: This agent presents little economic or animal health risk
notes: https://www.bing.com/newtabredir?url=https%3A%2F%2Fcongressionalsportsmen.org%2F

response: the Department of Commerce published a final rule in conjunction with a Department of State final rule to revise Categories I (firearms, close assault weapons and combat shotguns), II (guns and armaments), and III (ammunition/ordnance) of the United States Munitions List (USML) and transfer items that no longer warrant control on the USML in the International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR) to the Commerce Control List (CCL).

title: Update of Linear Right of Way Rent Schedule
ask: I am concerned about the significant impact these increases will have on the Sierra Pacific Resources, which in turn, could result in increased rates for my constiuents.
response: The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is amending its right-of-way regulations to update the linear right-of-way rent schedule in 43 CFR parts 2800 and 2880. The rent schedule covers most linear rights-of-way granted under Title V of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, as amended (FLPMA), and Section 28 of the Mineral Leasing Act of 1920, as amended (MLA). Those laws require the holder of a right-of-way grant to pay annually, in advance, the fair market value to occupy, use, or traverse public lands for facilities such as power lines, fiber optic lines, pipelines, roads, and ditches.

title: Comment on FR Doc # E8-16275
ask: I am writing this message to signal my support for oil shale development in the Colorado Plateau area and specifically in the Uintah Basin of Utah.
response: The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (EP Act) directs the Secretary of the Interior (Secretary) to: Make public lands available for conducting oil shale research and development activities; Complete a Programmatic Environmental Impact Statement (PEIS) for a commercial leasing program for both oil shale and tar sands resources on the BLM-administered lands in Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming; and Issue regulations establishing a commercial oil shale leasing program.

title: Comment on FR Doc # E8-16275
ask: This country is not ready for oil shale.
response: The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (EP Act) directs the Secretary of the Interior (Secretary) to: Make public lands available for conducting oil shale research and development activities; Complete a Programmatic Environmental Impact Statement (PEIS) for a commercial leasing program for both oil shale and tar sands resources on the BLM-administered lands in Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming; and Issue regulations establishing a commercial oil shale leasing program.

title: Comment on FR Docket #2012-11304
ask: We believe that the BLM's proposed rule will significantly delay oil and gas permitting and in turn discourage oil and gas production on our nation's land.
response: the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) published in the Federal Register a proposed rule to regulate hydraulic fracturing on public land and Indian land. The rule would require disclosure to the public of chemicals used in hydraulic fracturing on public land and Indian land, strengthen regulations related to well-bore integrity, and address issues related to flowback water.

title: Congressional Comment Letter (1)
notes: Late Comment

title: NM State Reps
organization: Representatives of the New Mexico State Legislature
ask: We urge you to withdraw the revisions. If you believe you need changes we also ask that you work with the counties and cities in the areas with substantial oil and gas production so that you do not disrupt the economic base of these communities.
response: The BLM disagrees with this interpretation of the new language and never intended for this rule to extend the BLM's permitting authority over State and private drilling approvals. However, to avoid confusion, the BLM in this final rule added a new paragraph (b) to its § 3161.1 revisions, which clarifies that it is the regulations in parts 3160 and 3170 relating to site security, measurement, reporting of production and operations, and assessments or penalties for non-compliance with such requirements (i.e., those found in subparts 3173, 3174, and 3175) that are applicable to all wells and facilities on State or privately owned lands committed to a unit or CA where the unit or CA affects Federal or Indian interests.

response: We issued a proposed rule on January 21, 2016, which was published on February 8, 2016, and accepted public comments through April 22, 2016, after extending the comment period. title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-01865
organization: Representatives of state and local governments from across New Mexico

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-01865
ask: I urge you to withdraw the proposed rule. I am concerned about the impact that the proposed rule could have on the ability of the oil and natural gas industry to develop resources domestically.
response: With respect to leaks, the final rule largely follows the proposed rule, except that the required frequency of inspection is set at two times a year, and does not vary according to the number of leaks found. Operators must use optical gas imaging equipment or portable analyzers deployed according to Method 21, and leaks must be repaired and retested within specified time frames. The final rule clarifies the approval process for alternative leak detection devices and for operators' individual alternative leak inspection programs.

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-01865
ask: Again, I urge the BLM to withdraw this rule and work closely with those with real-world knowledge to better understand this issue, including what solutions would be effective.
response: With respect to leaks, the final rule largely follows the proposed rule, except that the required frequency of inspection is set at two times a year, and does not vary according to the number of leaks found. title: V&F Senator Barrasso 4.26.16
ask: While I support efforts to reduce unnecessary venting and flaring of natural gas, I'm concerned that the rule fails to address a principal reason for flaring; protracted delays in the permitting of natural gas
response: While the BLM data indicate that the current speed of the BLM's ROW processing is not a significant factor in the rate of flaring at most wells, the BLM recognizes the importance of timely ROW approvals and continues to make improvements aimed at increasing the efficiency of the ROW permitting process.

title: V&F Comment_New Mexico Senate_4.20.16
ask: I would urge you to move very cautiously in your consideration of this proposed rule and to try to formulate an alternative which has a less draconian impact on the industry and the State of New Mexico.
response: With respect to leaks, the final rule largely follows the proposed rule, except that the required frequency of inspection is set at two times a year, and does not vary according to the number of leaks found. Operators must use optical gas imaging equipment or portable analyzers deployed according to Method 21, and leaks must be repaired and retested within specified time frames. The final rule clarifies the approval process for alternative leak detection devices and for operators' individual alternative leak inspection programs.

title: Senate of Pennsylvania
ask: Again, I respectfully urge the BLM to postpone the venting and flair rule and work closely with environmental and industry stakeholders, along with state and federal officials, to identify effective solutions to the continuing challenge of reducing methane emissions.
response: After the proposed rule was published on February 8, 2016, we conducted a second series of paired outreach meetings, with a tribal meeting each morning and a public meeting each afternoon. We held these meetings at four locations: Farmington, New Mexico (February 16, 2016), Oklahoma City, Oklahoma (February 18, 2016), Denver, Colorado (March 1, 2016), and Dickinson, North Dakota (March 3, 2016).

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-09439
ask: BLM's move to consolidate power and undermine local government involvement and influence in land planning is not in the best interest of Arizona or local communities and is not something that should be considered.
response: By operation of the Congressional Review Act (CRA), the Resource Management Planning Rule (Planning 2.0 Rule) shall be treated as if it had never taken effect. The BLM issues this document to effect the removal of any amendments, deletions or other modifications made by the nullified rule, and the reversion to the text of the regulations in effect immediately prior to the effective date of the Planning 2.0 Rule.

title: BLM0007841 Incoming
ask: Consequently, the rule should not be finalized. Instead, the BLM should engage with Alaska and the other states to revise the rule to ensure it properl y addresses the needs of the people directly impacted.
response: By operation of the Congressional Review Act (CRA), the Resource Management Planning Rule (Planning 2.0 Rule) shall be treated as if it had never taken effect. The BLM issues this document to effect the removal of any amendments, deletions or other modifications made by the nullified rule, and the reversion to the text of the regulations in effect immediately prior to the effective date of the Planning 2.0 Rule.

title: Congressional Letter-to-Sec-Zinke-on-BLM-Methane-Rule-Suspension
ask: We write in strong opposition to the Bureau of Land Management's recent announcement that it intends to pursue a new rulemaking to repeal or revise the agency's methane waste
response: The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is promulgating a final rule (2017 final delay rule) to temporarily suspend or delay certain requirements contained in the rule published in the Federal Register on November 18, 2016, entitled, “Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation” (2016 final rule) until January 17, 2019

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2018-03144
ask: We write in strong opposition to the Bureau of Land Management's (BLM) recent proposal to revise the 2016 Methane Waste Prevention rule.
response: The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is promulgating a final rule (2017 final delay rule) to temporarily suspend or delay certain requirements contained in the rule published in the Federal Register on November 18, 2016, entitled, “Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation” (2016 final rule) until January 17, 2019

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2018-03144
ask: As local, elected leaders from across Montana, we are deeply concerned by the U.S. Bureau of Land Management’s recent proposal to repeal major provisions of the 2016 Methane Waste Prevention Rule. Even more disconcerting is that the agency appears to be fast-tracking this rollback without holding a single hearing in any western state where oil and gas development on public lands takes place.
response: The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is promulgating a final rule (2017 final delay rule) to temporarily suspend or delay certain requirements contained in the rule published in the Federal Register on November 18, 2016, entitled, “Waste Prevention, Production Subject to Royalties, and Resource Conservation” (2016 final rule) until January 17, 2019

title: Comment from Senator Dennis Bradley, Connecticut State Senate
Comment on FR Doc # 2010-07728
organization: I don't write as representative of any organization.

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2020-25597
Comment on BSEE-2013-0011-0001
ask: On behalf of my constituents in the 84th Ohio House District, I am writing to demonstrate my strong support for oil and gas development in the Arctic Outer Continental Shelf (OCS)
ask1: Supports revisions to the proposed Arctic exploration rules to eliminate redundant standards, promote performance-based standards and provide that all measures are based on the practicalities of drilling in the Arctic
ask2: I support Shell’s plan to explore its leases in the Chukchi Sea in 2015. The company has invested significant time and resources in the advancement of safe and prudent Arctic exploration. Shell should be allowed to realize the promise of the leases it purchased and I encourage the BOEM to expeditiously approve its Exploration Plan.
ask3: Recommends that regulators synthesize current and evolving knowledge and validate technologies that could safely replace and provide a superior alternative to a same season relief well and/or oil spill containment systems

title: Comment on BSEE-2013-0011-0001
organization: U.S. Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

title: Comment on BSEE-2013-0011-0001
organization: U.S. Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources
ask: provide for an additional public comment period following any revisions to these proposed regulations
ask1: BSEE should consider a minimum of 14 days between tests and potentially every 21 days
ask2: clearer process and defined metrics should be provided for the agency's consideration of the alternative compliance measures to a standby relief rig requirement
ask3: consider the potential alternative of requiring a single IOP to be filed prior to an operator's first EP
response: As discussed in Section IV.A, Summary of Key Changes from the NPRM, in response to comments BSEE is adding a paragraph (i) to clarify when an operator is requesting approval of alternate compliance measures to the SCCE requirements under the provisions of § 250.141 and this final rule, the operator should demonstrate that the proposed alternate compliance measure provides a level of safety and environmental protection that meets or exceeds that required by BSEE regulations, including demonstrating that the alternate compliance measure will be capable of stopping or capturing the flow of an out-of-control well. These revisions are in response to commenters' concerns that the language as originally proposed did not clearly state a performance standard.;Three commenters commented on the frequency of IOP submissions. One commenter requested clarification on whether a single IOP could address Start Printed Page 46494multiple EPs. Another commenter requested that BOEM consider a single IOP filed prior to an operator's first EP. The third commenter suggests the IOP be updated when an EP is updated. BOEM disagrees that an IOP will need to be updated whenever an EP is updated. An IOP is required for each exploratory drilling program planned by an operator. However, a single IOP may cover multiple EPs when sufficient geographic and operational overlap exists. The IOP serves its primary purpose before an EP is submitted, as it informs the early planning process prior to initial EP submission. Requiring the IOP to be updated after the EP's submission would not serve any practical purpose, because the EP serves as the main point of reference for both agencies and the operator after the EP is filed.

title: Senator Cathy Giessel Arctic Comment

ask: ask for your reconsideration on these draft regulations
ask1: Integrated Operations Plan (IOP) requirement set forth in the draft regulations redundant with existing requirements
ask2: halves the current BSEE timeframe for a Blow-Out Preventer (BOP) pressure test;unnecessarily increases the wear and tear on assets
ask3: shortens an already small operating season in the Arctic
response: Many commenters generally criticized the IOP provision as being duplicative or redundant of existing requirements. BOEM disagrees. The IOP rules are neither redundant nor duplicative of existing requirements. The IOP is meant to be an overview of all phases of the operator's proposed operations in order to allow the Federal agencies an earlier review in the planning process than currently exists
notes: try to find a name for coalition

title: Comment from John  Coghill, Alaska Senate
Comment from John Coghill, Alaska Senate
ask: I am writing to share my strong support for oil and gas development in the Artic Outer Continental Shelf
ask1: I support revisions to the proposed Artic exploration rules. Generally, those revisions should include: (1) eliminating redundant standards; (2) promoting performance-based standards; and (3) providing that all measures are based on the practicalities of drilling in the Artic
ask2: Recommends that regulators synthesize current and evolving knowledge and validate technologies that could safely replace and provide a superior alternative to a same season relief well and/or oil spill containment systems

Comment on BSEE-2017-0008-0001

submitter_name: January 25, 2018 Dear Secretary Zinke, I am writing to express strong opposition to the Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement's (BSEE) proposed revisions to the Production Safety Systems rule. I am deeply concerned that BSEE's recent proposals will significantly weaken critical safety regulations that were adopted in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon tragedy and urge you to reject this ill-advised recommendation. I would also note that these regulations might have prevented the Deepwater Horizon spill in the first place. In 2016, BSEE finalized the Production Safety Systems rule, providing the first updates to drilling regulations since 1988. Specifically, the rule updated guidelines regulating acceptable drilling pressures at new drilling sites, in order to prevent surges and potential blowouts similar to what occurred in the Deepwater Horizon spill. The rule also imposed new requirements for emergency shutdown systems and strengthened BSEE rulemaking authority, permitting the agency to implement new industry standards into existing regulations. As you are undoubtedly aware, in 2016 BSEE adopted these regulations over the course of several years and after significant input and engagement with the public, federal policy makers, and industry stakeholders in order to enhance the safety of offshore oil and gas drilling. Now, less than two years after implementation, BSEE has suggested severely curtailing these regulations citing "potentially unduly burdensome requirements" on oil and gas operators. Some of the most noteworthy and egregious provisions of the proposal include: Removing the federal government's authority to regulate safe maximum or minimum drilling pressures at new drill sites. No longer requiring independent, third party auditors to certify that safety and pollution prevention equipment works under extreme conditions. Limiting BSEE's regulatory oversight by allowing oil and gas companies to adopt favorable industry standards for drilling methods. It is not only extremely premature to back off of these newly-implemented safety regulations, but it could also be catastrophic to Florida's pristine beaches and coastal economies. In fact, according to Miyoko Sakishima, director of the oceans program at the Center for Biological Diversity, BSEE's proposal "will put our coasts and wildlife at risk of more deadly oil spills." Sakishima went on to say that this "isn't just deregulation, it's willful ignorance." Furthermore, experts believe we are still years, if not decades, away from fully understanding the extent of the damage from the 2010 Deepwater Horizon spill. This is made evident by many of the environmental impacts we are still seeing today, including the detection of Deepwater Horizon oil in migratory bird's eggs 1,000 miles away in Minnesota, increased mortality rates for bottlenose dolphins and severe physical abnormalities among bluefin and yellowfin tuna populations. Many of Florida's coastal communities are still reeling from the oil spill and additional resources are needed to help these areas fully recover. To this end, BP announced an additional $1.7 billion for clean-up costs related to the oil spill, which now totals roughly $65 billion, and the company anticipates further payments of nearly $3 billion in 2018 to aid those seeking damages. If these safeguards are so burdensome then why is the oil industry enjoying record profits? The U.S. is currently producing over 10 million barrels of oil per day - a level we have not reached since the 1970s, rivaling the world's top producer, Russia. The Gulf of Mexico accounted for nearly 21 percent of all U.S. crude oil production in 2017, and with that number expected to increase in 2018 and beyond, now is not the time to place lives and our environment at risk by lifting these important safeguards. Florida's coastal communities depend on a clean and healthy ocean and we should not jeopardize the state's economy or environment by gambling on operations that lack adequate safeguards. While the environmental impact of the spill was immense and visible for all to see, Floridians also recall the vast economic damage done to the state, which totaled around $3 billion in lost visitor spending revenue, $182.5 million in lost sales tax, and 48,000 lost jobs. That is why I am asking you to reject any proposals to roll back regulations that were specifically adopted to address safety failures that led to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon spill. My constituents were severely impacted by the Deepwater Horizon spill, and we strongly oppose any effort to weaken these common-sense regulations that protect against another oil spill off the coast of Florida. I urge you to reject these ill-advised proposals. Don't weaken safety regulations for off-shore oil rigs. Thank you for your time and consideration, and I look forward to your prompt response on this critically important matter. Sincerely, Vern Buchanan Member of Congress
title: Comment on BSEE-2017-0008-0001
ask: do not weaken regulations
notes: interesting case - constituents affected by Deepwater Horizon

Comment from Garrett Fultz, Congressman Mike Johnson

submitter_name: March 10, 2020 The Honorable Mary Neumayr Chairman Council on Environmental Quality 730 Jackson Place, NW Washington, DC 20503 Dear Chairman Neumayr: I write to you in support of the Council on Environmental Quality's (CEQ) proposed rule to update procedural regulations of the national Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). While NEPA's goal of factoring impacts to the environment into the federal decision-making process is well-intended, the statute's procedural requirements have stifled development and morphed into a vehicle for costly and time-consuming litigation. CEQ's proposed revisions to streamline the NEPA process can provide a much-needed jolt to stimulate projects across the country while maintaining the integrity of the environmental review process. I am particularly encouraged by CEQ's proposal to (1) set a two-year time limit for the preparation of an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS); and (2) provide clarity regarding the requirement to consider alternatives to the proposed action. Although there are many examples to illustrate NEPA's glaring inefficiencies, one project in my Congressional District may be particularly insightful for CEQ. The proposed I-49 Inner-City Connector in Shreveport, Louisiana would unify a disjointed segment of I-49 that stretches approximately 3.8 miles. The Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) announced the original Notice of Intent (NOI) to unify I-49 in February 2012. The project is over eight years into the NEPA process, and there is not even a draft-EIS for agency review and Public comment. For reference, in CEQ's own "Forty Questions" document answering NEPA-related questions, the Council wrote "even large complex energy projects would require only about 12 months for the completion of the entire EIS process." A 3.8 mile stretch of highway is a far cry from some of our country's most complex energy infrastructure. The statute has clearly grown beyond its intended scope. In my view, NEPA's vague and amorphous requirement to consider alternatives to the proposed action is one of the primary reasons for delay in the I-49 project. Instead of remaining committed to the original project goal of unifying I-49 through the construction of a 3.8-mile roadway, FHWA modified the purpose of the project to allow the consideration of an alternative that is neither technically nor economically feasible. In fact, this alternative would cost hundreds of millions of dollars more than the originally-proposed 3.8-mile project, and it would require the deconstruction of an interchange with engineering characteristics found nowhere else in Louisiana. I am encouraged by CEQ's acknowledgment in the proposed rule that consideration of unreasonable alternatives can divert limited agency resources, and I respectfully urge the council to require suggested alternatives to a proposed action to be both technically and economically feasible. For decades, NEPA's seemingly innocuous requirement to incorporate environmental impacts into the federal decision-making process has resulted in significant time delays and job-killing cost overruns. Ultimately, my constituents are left with a disjointed I-49 with no resolution in sight, and there are countless other projects waiting in limbo across the country. This lack of action and certainty was not always the status quo. As President Trump explained, "America is a nation of builders. It took four years to build the Golden Gate Bridge, five years to build the Hoover Dam, and less than one year...to build the Empire State Building." We can get back on track in this area through common-sense NEPA reform, and we can accomplish our goals while still upholding our duties to be good stewards of the environment. It should not take more than 8 years to conduct the environmental review to construct 3.8 miles of highway. That is why I fully support CEQ's proposed regulatory changes to this burdensome statute. I look forward to seeing the implementation of this proposed rulemaking and others like it. Sincerely, Mike Johnson Member of Congress
title: Comment from Garrett Fultz, Congressman Mike Johnson

org_name: Jeffrey Merkley, Richard Durbin, Sherrod Brown, Chris Coons, Jack Reed, Kirsten Gillibrand, Edward Markey, Al Franken, Tammy Baldwin, Bernard Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, Sheldon Whitehouse, Martin Heinrich, Ron Wyden, Richard Blumenthal, Patty Murray, Patrick Leahy Dianne Feinstein, Mazie Hirono, Barbara Boxer, Tom Udall, Ropert Casey Jr., Corey Booker, Maria Cantwell, Barbara Mikulski, Benjamin Cardin, Christopher Murphy, Charles Schumer;  ;coalition
ask: we encourage the CFPB to strengthen certain protections in the proposed rule to ensure the strongest possible defense against the predatory lending models that trap consumers in unaffordable and escalating cycles of debt.
ask1: We urge the CFPB to reconsider the six loan exemption and implement strong ability to repay requirements.
ask2: We also encomage you to strengthen the analysis that lenders must undetiake to ensure that borrowers have enough money to pay all basic living expenses.
ask3: Additionally, we are concerned about the reduced cooling off, or waiting, period between loans from 60 days in the CFPB's preliminary proposal to 30 days in the proposed rule.

title: 2016.10.11 Ellison to RC_payday NPRM
ask: In conclusion, this proposed rule is long overdue. Our nation need a more robust and consumerfriendly small-dollar loan market.
ask1: Origination fees for all small-dollar loans should be banned.
ask2: In order to expand access to low-cost small dollar loans, the CFPB should allow a five percent of income payment option. The March 2015 proposal allowed this “longer-term alternative,” however that option was removed in the draft rule.
ask3: Finally, the CFPB should not provide incentives for lenders to collect on 95% of loans
notes: this guy has some weirdly specific requests that don't seem to align with the rest of the coalition perfectly - only somewhat

title: Comment Submitted by Montana State Senator Christine Kaufmann, Montana Organizing Project
ask: The current proposal is a good start, but it must be strengthened to be effective.
ask1: The waiting period between loans should be extended from 30 days to at least 60 days
ask2: Currently, up to six high-cost payday loans could be exempted from the ability to repay standard, leav ing borrowers in debt for much of the year

title: Comment Submitted by Rep. John P. Cyrier
ask: I urge the CFPB to vacate the rules under consideration until it does the necessary work to thoroughly consider the impact that eliminating access to credit will have on Texans.

title: Comment Submitted by Jim Murphy, Texas House of Representatives
ask: I urge the Bureau to stop this Washington knows best approach in regulating the financial services marketplace and consult with state legislator's from Texas and elsewhere to propose a pathway that ensure equitable credit

title: Comment by Daniel J. Burke
ask: I strongly urge the CFPB to reassess its top-down approach to regulating the financial services marketplace, and work with state legislators in Illinois and other parts of the country to write new rules targeting lending industry crooks.

title: Comment by William P. Coley, II
ask: I encourage the CFPB to reconsider its proposed regulations until the economic and social impact of such actions can be effectively studied.

title: Comment by Richard DeBolt
organization: State of Washington House of Representatives
ask:
Washington State already has some of the most tightly-regulated payday lending laws in the
nation. I strongly urge the Bureau to stop progress on the proposed payday lending rule and consider other options for approaching the problems with the industry, such as many of the reforms we have proposed here in Washington State.

title: Comment submitted by Dan Flynn, Texas House of Representatives
ask: I urge the CFPB to reconsider its adoption of the proposed rules. If the Bureau does not do this, it is most likely that the short-term lending industry, which serves a necessary purpose in my state, will be eliminated.

title: Comment Submitted by Ron  Simmons , State Representative Ron Simmons
ask: I am writing to express my unease over the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s proposed shortterm lending rule. I believe the CFPB has failed to fully understand the potential consequences of this rule and am concerned the proposed regulations will hurt both small businesses and consumers in my district.

title: Comment Submitted by Konni Burton, Texas State Senate
ask: Our state does not need the CFPB, a Washington-based agency that lacks understanding of short-term borrowers in my district and across the state, to preempt our careful work with sweeping federal regulations.

title: Comment Submitted by Tracy Morehead, Texas State Representative, District 56
ask: I urge the Bureau to reevaluate the proposal, starting with collecting more objective data that thoroughly considers the views of the industry and the needs of the consumer, and to consider market driven policy that more efficiently balances the need for credit with consumer protections. If the federal government feels obligated to regulate the industry, focus on dangerous, unregulated providers that present clear dangers to the public
ask1: . If the federal government feels obligated to regulate the industry, focus on dangerous, unregulated providers that present clear dangers to the public

title: Comment Submitted by Alice Vickers, Members of the Florida House of Representatives and The Florida Senate who signed the comment
organization: Members of the Florida House of Representatives and The Florida Senate who signed the comment
org_name: Thompson, Geraldine; Dudley, Dwight; Clarke-Reed, Gwendolyn; Berman, Lori; Stafford, Cynthia; Jenne, Evan; Rogers, Hazel; Bullard, Dwight; Pafford, Mark
ask: The CFPB’s proposed rule is an important step forward for millions of Americans and for the people of Florida struggling to escape the debt trap, but it must be strengthened to be effective. It is critically important that the CFPB close loopholes in the proposed rules.
ask1: A determination of the ability to repay the loan is a protection for families that should be required in all loans made. The Bureau should strengthen this part of the rule, closing the loophole that would allow lenders exemptions from this requirement

title: Comment Submitted by Alice Forgy Kerr, Commonwealth of Kentucky State Senate
ask: The rule is a critical first step in stopping the harms ofunaffordable loans, but the rule must be strengthened to ensure it stops the debt trap once and for all.
ask1: I feel strongly that the ability to repay requirement should apply to all short-term and long-term high cost loans. There is no valid reason why high cost lenders should get a pass on such a critical responsible lending norm.
ask2: I believe there are weaknesses in the proposed ability to repay test that need to be remedied. The proposal does not go far enough to ensure that borrowers will be able to pay their expenses and have enough money to live on after making the loan payment. The rule should not allow a lender to simply forecast a borrower's living expenses based on a percent of income or other factors. Lenders should be required to review a borrower's basic living expenses and avoid over-reliance on back-end measures like default and reborrowing rates.
ask3: I also hope that the CFPB will change the cooling off period back to 60 days, as it was in the original draft proposal.

title: Comment Submitted by Will Ainsworth, State Representative Will Ainsworth
ask: I am writing to express my concern about the CFPB's proposed regulations on payday, title, and other short-term lending products
notes: this guy has the sloppiest least complex letter I've seen

title: Comment Submitted by Deisy Jaimes, Office of StateSenator Jose Rodriguez
ask: These are all important measures, but we are concerned that without strengthening them, many of them could be rendered ineffective. The following aspects of the rule should be addressed to ensure that lenders cannot continue their predatory practices
ask1: Require ability to repay standard for all loans, with no exceptions: The core principle of the CFPB’s proposal is the right approach – requiring payday and auto title
ask2: Long-term loans need added protections to ensure affordable terms: As the rule stands, there are few protections from a likely scenario of increasing the length of the loan term in order to cloak unaffordability. Though Texas state law and the city ordinances include payment limitations and effective limitations on the length of the loan, the online space in Texas includes many lenders that evade state consumer lending laws. One Texas borrower asked for help, because she was buried under a $2,500 4-year loan that included a total repayment of $13,000. When she asked for help, she had already paid $9,000 on the loan and still owed much of the principal. Under the current longterm lending proposal, this loan could meet an affordability test, unless there are further objective standards in the rule, such as a hard backend default rate that elevates regulatory scrutiny, and a front-end loan term standard to ensure that loan terms are commensurate with the size of the loan.12
ask3: Strengthen protections against loan flipping: We are concerned that the proposed rule does not go far enough to prevent the flipping of borrowers from one unaffordable loan to the next. Borrowers’ short-term debt should not become unaffordable long-term debt; to help, the CFPB should change the cooling off period to 60 days, rather than just 30 days as proposed, between each short-term loan

title: Comment Submitted by Olivia Alperstein, Progressive Congress Action Fund
ask: the federal government must ensure that vulnerable consumers are not taken advantage of and conned into agreeing to confusing and misleading loan terms that they do not and cannot be expected to understand.
ask1: We urge the CFPB to ensure a reasonable determination of a borrowers ability to repay any high-cost loan
ask2: to set a reasonable cap on the interest that may be charged on any such loan
ask3: We urge the CFPB, furthermore, to adopt a stipulation in the proposed rule that would prevent and punish the general practice of irresponsibly targeting high-risk populations for certain types of high-cost loans.

title: Comment by Deborah Long
ask: I am writing to object to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's proposed short-term lending rule as it is clear that the Bureau is attempting to fix a market it wrongly assumes is in disarray, while the reality is that consumers are already well-served by the existing state-regulated marketplace.

title: Comment by Rick Gudex
ask: I urge the Bureau to slow down, reconsider·its actions, and take into account that some of us have . already taken the necessary and, to our citizens, acceptable steps to do this work.

title: Comment by Nickie Antonio
ask: I urge th~ CFPB to set strong product safety standards that curb the harms of payday loans in Ohio a~c;f that give banks and credit unions clear guidance on how to better servt;! their own customers. I .'
ask1: I encourage the CFPB to include product safety standards in its proposal, such as limiting installment payments to an affordable share of a borrower's paycheck;
ask2: requiring that lenders give borrowers a reasonable amount of time to repay their loans
ask3: prohibiting large origination fees that encourage lenders to refinance borrowers frequently.

title: Comment by David Derby
ask: I argue the CFPB should reconsider its rules after collecting new research and more thoroughly considering the views of consumers. industry experts and state policymakers.

title: Comment submitted by Congresswoman Lois Frankel
Comment from Representatives David Scott, Sanford Bishop, Jim Costa, Brad Ashford, and Krysten Sinema
ask: We are especially appreciative of the safeguards and protections in the proposed rule intended to help borrowers escape the cycle of debt. We write today with several suggestions that, we believe, could strengthen the rule and help ensure sufficient access to small dollar loans for our constituents.
ask1: we are concerned that the ability-to-repay (ATR) requirements may be too complex making it unduly burdensome for consumers to qualify for small dollar credit. After reviewing the proposed rule, four of the leading specialty credit bureaus have raised serious concerns that consumers who make less than $40,000 annually are either unlikely to qualify for a $500 loan or the underwriting costs would be so burdensome that the risks of making such a loan would outweigh the benefits.

title: Comment from Representatives Chuck Fleischmann, Scott DesJairlais, David R. Poe, Stephen Fincher, John Duncan, Marsha Blackburn, Diane Black
ask: We urge the CFPB to reconsider its proposed regulation, which eliminates access to short-term credit for o.ur constituents.

ask: We urge the CFPB to reconsider its proposed regulation, which eliminates access to short-term credit for o.ur constituents.

ask: We urge the CFPB to reconsider its proposed regulation, which eliminates access to short-term credit for o.ur constituents.

title: Comment from Representatives Chuck Fleischmann, Scott DesJairlais, David R. Poe, Stephen Fincher, John Duncan, Marsha Blackburn, Diane Black
org_name: DUNCAN, John J., Jr.; Roe, David; DesJarlais, Scott
ask: We urge the CFPB to reconsider its proposed regulation, which eliminates access to short-term credit for o.ur constituents.

title: Comment Submitted by Scott Biggs, House of Representatives State of Oklahoma
ask: Unfortunately, the Bureau has proposed rules on small dollar lending do not fit within this designated purpose. In fact, the rule will devastate the consumer credit industry and limit access to regulated credit. This rule will ultimately harm those it is supposed to protect.

title: Comment Submitted by Chad Caldwell, House of Representatives State of Oklahoma
ask: Unfortunately, the Bureau wants to overrule our proven regulatory structure, which our legislature crafted and refined by paying attention to our constituents and understanding their needs.

title: Comment Submitted by Jon Echols, House of Representatives State of Oklahoma
ask: There simply is no basis for 1,333 pages of proposed federal rules designed to put consumer credit lenders out of business. Thesejicensed lenders provide emergency credit to Oklahoma consumers who have no practical alternatives for financial shortfalls. The banks will not loan such smalj amounts and charitable pilot projects have not proven viable. These overly burdensome and capricious fedr ral regulations will force Qklahomans to rely on more expensive, less regulated alternatives.

title: Comment Submitted by James Leewright, House of Representatives State of Oklahoma
ask: I appreciate the opportunity to provide comment in opposition to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's rule regarding small dollar lending. Unfortunately, Bureau officials are clearly seeking to override the laws of states, such as Oklahoma, that have consistently demonstrated effective regulation of consumer lending.

title: Comment Submitted by Pat Ownbey, House of Representatives State of Oklahoma
ask: A rule such as this does not work for consumers, and therefore simply doesn't work. The Bureau should focus on eliminating unregulated lending and support existing state laws that afford consumers the opportunity for muchneeded credit in a licensed, regulated environment.

title: Comment Submitted by Scooter Park, House of Representatives State of Oklahoma
ask: he Bureau's proposal is a clear attempt to take away state's authority to enact their own laws that effectively govern short term lending.

title: Comment from Tyler August, State Representative, Wisconsin State Assembly
ask: On behalf of the state of Wisconsin, I urge the CFPB to change the focus of its rulemaking from usurping the role of the state government and address the larger problem of the dangers of unregulated lending. Thank you for your consideration

title: Comment from Cecil Bell, Texas House of Representatives
ask: I am voicing my concerns over the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's proposed short-term lending rule

title: Comment from Jodie Laubenberg, Texas House of Representatives
ask:
The lone Star state does not need the CFPB's shortsighted and overbearing federal regulations replacing our existing laws,
especially given that the Bureau has never identified any failings in our regulatory framework.

title: Comment Submitted by Justin Wood, House of Representatives State of Oklamaho
ask: These regulations fall short in a number of different areas, which is not altogether surprising given the CFPB's reliance on flawed and ill-advised research when constructing these rules. With the sole intention to destroy the short-term lending industry, the CFPB elitist approach harms the very consumer it purports to try and protect. When the CFPB eliminates the industry, it will leave my constituents unable to seek the services of legitimate lenders who offer a host important common sense protections.

title: Comment submitted by Joel Bomgar, Mississippi House of Representatives
ask: By over-regulating the payday loan industry, the CFPB is doing a great deal of harm to consumers. I trust that the CFPB will take these concerns into consideration, and for the reasons that I have stated above I hope that the CFPB will discontinue their efforts to regulate payday loans. State legislatures have regulated the payday loan industry for decades - please allow us to continue to do so.

title: Comment submitted by Garry R. Smith, South Carolina House of Representatives
ask: Consumers benefit from having many financial options and the freedom to choose the service that best suits their personal needs. As a government agency, the CFPB has an obligation to listen to consumers and draft regulations that both reflect their preferences and foster an · equitable marketplace. Unfortunately, the Bureau's proposal fails miserably on both counts. It enables high-cost and highrisk alternatives, including unlicensed operations, while hurting small businesses that providtconsumers regulated payday loans that they can afford. This unilateral action would effectively shut down the entire regulated payday lending industry-a huge blow to business across South Carolina and the communities they serve.

title: Comment submitted by Willie Simmons, Mississippi State Senate
ask: I wish to make you aware of my concerns over the recently proposed CFPB rules regarding payday loans. It seems as though these rules have been proposed, not to protect consumers, but instead to over-regulate the payday loan industry out of business. This greatly concerns me because I know that many of my constituents rely on payday loans as their only available means of cr~dit. This valuabie ·means of credit wi ll no longer be available if the payday loan industry can no longer afford to stay in business due to the over-regulation of the federal government.

title: Comment submitted by Michael T. Evans, Mississippi House of Representatives
ask: I wish to make you aware of my concerns over the recently proposed CFPB rules regarding payday loans. It seems as though these rules have been proposed, not to protect consumers, but instead to over-regulate the payday loan industry out of business. This greatly concerns me because I know that many of my constituents rely on payday loans as their only available means of credit. This valuable means of credit will no longer be available if the payday loan industry can no longer afford to stay in business due to the over-regulation ofthe federal government.

title: Comment submitted by Steve McManus, Tennessee House of Representatives
ask: The proposed rule presents a number of issues for my constituency, but I am most concerned with the federal government's arrogant attempt to regu late an issue that falls within the purview of the states' authority.

title: Comment submitted by Larry Hall, North Carolina House of Representatives
ask: Please close the loopholes in your rule and issue the strongest rule possible to stop the payday loan debt trap.
ask1: We also ask that you strictly enforce the important principle of ability-to-repay.

title: Comment submitted by Stephen L. Nass, Wisconsin State Senate
ask: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's (CFPB) proposed regulation on short-term lending is an overreach of federal authority and unnecessarily infringes on the regulatory authority of the states. For many years, Wisconsin legislators and governors have debated and passed legislation regulating the short-term lending industry to protect our citizens from unfair predatory practices. I am not convinced of the need for the federal bureaucracy to preempt the legitimate role that our state government has in providing a regulatory framework that benefits and protects our citizens.

title: Comment submitted by Greg Beumer, Indiana House of Representatives
ask: The federal government cannot create a "one size fits all" rule that can be effective for all 50 states. What works for one state may not work for another - which is why there is a variation in the state laws that govern small-dollar credit products today. Some states have a large market for small-dollar credit products, while others do not. The beauty of the current system is that we, as individual states, get to determine what our citizenry needs, and then we create a regulatory scheme that allows businesses to flourish while also protecting the interests of our citizens.

title: Comment submitted by Terry Burton, Mississippi State Senate
ask: I wish to make you aware of my concerns over the recently proposed CFPB rules regarding payday loans. It seems as though these rules have been proposed, not to protect consumers, but instead to over-regulate the payday loan industry out of business. This greatly concerns me because I know that many of my constituents rely on payday loans as their only available means of credit. This valuable means of credit will no longer be available if the payday loan industry can no longer afford to stay in business due to the over-regulation of the federal government.

The CFPB's proposed regulations for the payday lending industry have raised considerable concerns in Idaho. It appears the CFPB has designed these proposals to entirely eliminate this industry, leaving many Idaho citizens without access to important and credible short-term credit options.

title: Comment submitted by Credell Calhoun, Mississippi House of Representatives
ask: By over-reguiating the payday loan industry, the CFPB is doing a great deal of harm to consumers. These proposed regulations will lead to consumers seeking out loans from unregulated internet lenders. When that happens, we will no longer be able to ensure that consumers will be protected.

title: Comment submitted by David Mack III, South Carolina House of Representatives
ask: The CFPB's regulations will stand in conflict with and override our carefully drafted laws designed with our constituents' best interests in mind. Once these regulations are in place, it will be bad for the consumer. It would leave borrowers with a limited short-term lending market. The CFPB's rule, regulating all lenders indiscriminately, will leave small-dollar credit providers unable to serve their customers' financial needs and would represent a huge opportunity for unlicensed lenders currently operating on the black market

title: Comment submitted by Jacqueline Y. Collins, Illinois State Senate
ask: In. particular, I 1 fear .this prop.osed· ·rule will have unintended and negative consequences in lllinois, cutting off access to credit and thus driving consumers toward less regulated alternatives. Under Illinois' cun·ent legal and regulatory structure, consumers continue to have access to safe and well-regulated.lending options

title: Comment submitted by Rob Hutton, Wisconsin House of Representatives
ask: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's proposed regulation on short-term lending is an overreach on federal authority and will have unintended negative consequences for the hardworking citizens of Wisconsin.

title: Comment submitted by Steve Pugh, Louisiana House of Representatives
ask: I am writing to express my concern over the recently proposed rules regarding short-term, small-dollar cred it products. These proposed rules have caused me a great deal of apprehension for a number of different reasons. Most notably, I am concerned over the fact that the proposed rule is a long-winded I ,334 pages in length, making the rules exceptionally difficult for borrowers to understand.

title: Comment submitted by Bill Reineke, Ohio House of Representatives
ask: As a businessman, I understand the importance ofhaving access to credit. Consumers need a wide variety of options available to them in the marketplace to find the right product that meets their needs. The current set of regulations proposed by the Consumer Finance Protection Bureau concerns me in that they will limit the consumer's ability to obtain short-term credit.

title: Comment Submitted by Senator Lizbeth Benacquisto, Florida Senate
ask: As a member of the Florida Senate, I find it unclear why the federal government is proposing a rule, purportedly to protect consumers, which could wipe out Florida's effective, consumerfriendly system of regulating payday lenders. I strongly urge the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to reconsider its proposed rule and instead embrace the Florida model as a guide for the nation.

title: Comment Submitted by Senator Rob Bradley, Florida Senate
ask: I am writing to express my concerns about the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's proposed new rules for short-term lending.

title: Comment Submitted by Mike Miller, Florida House of Representatives
ask: In the discussion regarding the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's proposed new rules for short-term lending, one voice has been conspicuously missing: that of consumers. I have heard from my constituents, and those who find themselves in need of occasional short-t erm loans are deeply worried about their future if the new rules are implemented.

title: Comment Submitted by Dane Eagle, Florida House of Representatives
ask: I write to express my concern about a rule proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau that would preempt Florida Jaw with respect to short-term payday loans. As an elected Member of the Florida House of Representatives, I am very concerned the proposed rule will wipe out Florida's tremendously effective, consumer-friendly system of regulating payday lenders.

title: Comment Submitted by Senator Audrey Gibson, Florida Senate
ask: Undoubtedly, there are states whose regulatory systems fail to offer their residents the short-term loan protections that Florida consumers benefit from. However, those states should deal with the dilemma of their own systems though perhaps adopting Florida's methods of correcting the system, or the CFPB could establish a single federal standard, based on Florida's excellent approach.

title: Comment Submitted by Senator Garrett Richter, Florida Senate
ask: On behalf of my constituents and all the consumers of Florida, I encourage CFPB to amend its proposed rules. I r it feels compelled to impose a single federal standard on the entire nation, CFPB should instead adopt the Florida model. In this way. it can ensure the co ntinued ~ ava ilability of short-term cash to those who need it while protecting borrowers from the pitfalls of a less consumer-friendly approach.

title: Comment Submitted by Jim Boyd, Florida House of Representatives
ask: The proposed CFPB rule would topple this effective system, which has worked well for millions of residents of the nation's third largest state, and replace it with such a confining approach that most consumers would find themselves cut off from ready access to short-term cash. This change would result in consumers losing an effective and popular option for managing life's financial challenges, likely driving them to more expensive and less regulated alternatives.

title: Comment Submitted by Van  Taylor, Texas Senate
ask: While thoughtful legislators on all sides of the political spectrum can debate access to short-term credit, attempting to do without legislative approval violates our nation's system of checks and balances. In order for a bill to become law it must withstand public scrutiny, expert testimony, and votes from elected officials who represent the voice of their constituents. The attempt of an agency to make law void of the legislative process opens the door to a host of unintended consequences and poor policy decisions.

title: Comment Submitted by James Frank, Oklahoma State Senate
ask: The CFPB proposal not only would create significant economic distress for business and consumers, but also infringes upon the privacy of small-dollar borrowers. By creating a generalized federal mandate, the Bureau ignores Texas’s ability to effectively regulate the short-term lending industry. I urge the CFPB to reconsider its proposal and instead focus on eliminating unregulated lending. This would serve to improve protections for consumers without causing substantial harm to the people of Texas.

title: Comment Submitted by Senator Patricia Bates California State Senate_0927_2
ask: Please do not force the citizens of my state to resort to finding credit from the unregulated, unlicensed internet lending market. The CFPB should discontinue efforts to regulate small-dollar loans in the states. By allowing the states to regulate themselves, we can ensure that our citizens retain their access to credit in a safe and regulated environment.

title: Comment Submitted by Senator Daniel Biss Illinois 9th Senate District_1007_2
ask: Families and communities in Illinois need strong rules from the CFPB. While I commend the CFPB for taking this important step in regulating the industry, I believe that the rules can and should be strengthened to make the loans safer and less costly.
ask1: Strengthen Ability-to-Repay: All loans should be required to meet the ability-to-repay standards set in the proposed rules. As we have seen in Illinois, payday and title lenders will exploit any loophole. I recommend that the CFPB remove the exceptions to the ability-to-repay rule.
ask2: Increase Time Between Loans: Families are suffocating from debt. Numerous high-interest loans put too much strain on a household budget. A longer cooling off period between loans will provide households with some breathing room. I recommend that the CFPB extend the “cooling off” period between loans from 30 days to 60 days.
ask3: Curb Long Loan Terms: Over the last 9 years there has been an increase in the length of a loan’s terms. This means that borrowers are paying back more over a longer period of time – extending the period of holding high-cost debt. I recommend that the CFPB curb lengthy loan periods by limiting the length of all loans.

title: Comment Submitted by Representative Mike Miller Florida House of Representatives_09162016_2
ask: In its relentless determination to drive payday lenders out of business, CFPB seems to be looking at short-term loans in a vacuum. It appears they have not carefully considered the impact of the Rule upon the citizens of our state, nor has it engaged in meaningful consultation with the States regarding preemption of their laws and rules. As a result, they are creating brand new “one-size-fits-all” regulations that have not been tested in the real world.

title: Comment Submitted by Rep Matthew Lesser House Democrats, Senate Democrats, House Republicans and Senate Republicans_cov_0902_fin
organization: House Democrats, Senate Democrats, House Republicans and Senate Republicans
org_name: Lesser Matthew; Winfield, Gary; Simanski, Bill; Riley Emmett; Vargas, Ed; Rose, Kim; Gentile Linda; Godrey, Bob; Albis, James; Rojas, Jason; Baram, David; Ryan, Kevin; Flexer, Mae; Berger, Jeff; Lemar, Roland; Porter, Robyn; Gerratana Terry; Bartolomeo, Dante; MacLachlan, Michael
ask: As Connecticut legislators, we commend the proposed rule for strongly conforming to Connecticut public policy regarding small loan lending. In a few areas, we ask that the CFPB strengthen the proposed rule to protect the rights of states to enforce our existing consumer financial laws.
ask1: Lastly, we urge the CFPB to adopt a strong ability-to-repay standard. Each of us has been elected to represent constituents who are burdened by cycles of debt and poverty. Ensuring that borrowers have the ability to repay the loans they take out is simply common sense and in full accordance with the interests of our constituents
ask2: we urge you to include fees and other costs in calculating interest rates as provided for under the MLA. This commonsense approach makes it harder for lenders to mask the true cost of debt or evade rate caps.
ask3: (2) urge you to consider making a violation of state lending laws an unfair, deceptive or abusive practice under Dodd-Frank.

ask: For these reasons, 1 respectfully request that you reconsider this proposal.

title: Comment Submitted by Cole Wist, Colorado House of Representatives
ask: I am writing to relay my concerns regarding the CFPB's proposed rules on short-term, small dollar installment loans. Colorado has already taken the necessary steps to implement regulations that establish an appropriate balance between consumer protection and the availability of affordable credit. I am concerned that the proposed federal approach is unnecessary and will, in fact, undermine our efforts at the state level. A federal, one size fits all approach is not appropriate or in the best interest of Coloradans. I urge the CFPB to study and perform due diligence on states like Colorado that have a proven track record of regulating payday loans.

title: Comment Submitted by Brad Sherman_United State Congress
ask: As the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) considers proposed new rules and regulations intended to protect consumers, I urge that it takes no action that restricts my choice of credit options. Every day, millions of American consumers like me depend on short term and small dollar loans to manage their finances. These alternative sources of credit help consumers get funds quickly when we have financial emergencies and also help us avoid expensive overdraft and late payment fees from banks and credit card companies.
notes: Forwarding constituent mail without any stated opinion

title: Comment Submitted by Ben Hueso, California State Senator 40th District

ask: In crafting the proposed rules, the Bureau failed to take into account state laws and regulations that already effectively govern short term credit.
ask1: Bureau’s proposal will overrule Oklahoma’s state laws governing short term credit and completely ignore the needs of consumers who use this credit responsibly.
ask2: I urge the CFPB to reconsider the proposed rule by studying and applying effective state regulatory models, such as Oklahoma.
response: The Bureau believed that the proposed $500 limit for the first loan was appropriate in light of current State regulatory limits and would reduce the risks that unaffordable payments would cause consumers to default, re-borrow, or fail to meet basic living expenses or other major financial obligations during a loan sequence.

org_name: Robert Menendez;Sherrod Brown;Catherine Cortez Masto;Cory A. Booker;Kirsten Gillibrand;Chris Van Hollen;Richard Blumenthal;Tammy Duckworth;Jack Reed;Tammy Baldwin;Elizabeth Warren;Benjamin L. Cardin;Kamala D. Harris;Edward J. Markey;Doug Jones;Angus S. King, Jr.;Dianne Feinstein;Richard J. Durbin;Bernard Sanders;Tina Smith;Sheldon Whitehouse;Amy Klobuchar;Brian Schatz;Mazie K. Hirono;Ron Wyden;Jeffrey A. Merkley
ask: Yet, the CFPB’s proposed rule-contains no requirement that.a debt collector have original documentation or other information to substantiate that the debt they are attempting to collect is legitimately owed by the: onsumer they are contacting.
ask1: s itis cutrently written, the proposed debt collection rule will only exacerbate and increase troubling harassment tactics..By allowing debt collectors to send consumers unlimited text messages and emails without first receiving affirmative.consent.for such a method of communication, the proposed rule permits collectors. to overwhelm consumers with intrusive communications.
ask2: The proposed rule allows a debt collector to call.a consumer seven times a week per debt. For a.consumer with six-medical debts, the proposed rulemeans-that the-consumer eould receive up to 42 calls per week. Furthermore, creating an exemption for “limited content” messages that could be overheard on a voicemail or delivered to third parties like an employer is an invasion of basic privacy that should not be-endorsed by. the: Bureau.
ask3: The rule also weakeits-protections. for consumers whose debts are no longer enforceable under ‘state or federal law. Rather than simply bannitig collection of time-barred debt by third party collectors, the GFPB’s rulé provides collectors with a.loophole to:mislead borrowérs inte unknowingly accepting liability for those debts,
response: The Bureau also declines to expand the prohibition in § 1006.30(b)(1) to encompass other types of debt beyond debt that has been paid or settled or discharged in bankruptcy. The Bureau concludes that the transfer of time-barred debt, disputed debt, debt lacking ownership documentation, debt subject to litigation, debt in which the consumer has an uncompleted settlement agreement, or other types of debt suggested by commenters do not present the same unfairness and unconscionability concerns of the same prevalence and magnitude as the debt types to which the prohibition in § 1006.30(b)(1) applies.

ask: call consumers seven times per week, per debt, potentially leading to scores of calls to consumers with multiple debts in collection,
ask1: text and email without clear limits and without consumers’ consent, and send legally required notices through hyperlinks consumers might be afraid to click on,

ask: I request that the CFPB collaborate with the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to conduct—and make public—a formal review of the privacy, health, and financial implications of this proposed regulation and incorporate the results into any rulemaking.
ask1: the proposed rule fails to protect patients and their private health information from a pernicious new trend in medical debt collection: the use of social media platforms and texting to contact consumers.
ask2: For such entities, the use of social media platforms without a patient’s prior consent appears likely to constitute an unauthorized breach of protected health information.

title: Comment submitted by Alex X. Mooney on behalf of Congress
Alex X. Mooney on behalf of Congress
ask: I respectfully urge you to remove the safe harbor provision for meaningful attorney involvement from the final version of the debt collection rule.
success3: The Bureau received a large number of comments on the proposed meaningful attorney involvement safe harbor from a variety of commenters, almost all of whom opposed the proposal. As discussed below, the Bureau has decided after considering the comments not to finalize the proposed provision regarding meaningful attorney involvement.

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-31727
Comment on FR Doc # 2016-31727
Comment on FR Doc # 2016-31727
Comment on FR Doc # 2016-12451
Comment on FR Doc # 2016-12451
Comment on FR Doc # 2016-12451
coalition: national association of state board of education
ask: In light of the foregoing reasons, I urge you to reconsider the Department's decision to discipline school districts for low test participation rates.
response: The Department would retain authority under the final regulations to address technical or logistical anomalies related to State administration of the annual assessments required by the Act that have a negative impact on the ability of schools to meet the 95 percent participation rate requirement.
pressure_phrases: One commenter expressed concern that the proposed actions for schools that miss the 95 percent participation rate requirement would not permit flexibility when technical issues, such as the failure of computer networks, affect test participation rates.

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-12451
Comment on FR Doc # 2016-12451
coalition: national association of state board of education
ask: As such, I believe that the regulations should call for states to be transparent in disclosing the methodology they employ in measuring school performance to give the Department the oversight capability called for in ESSA. The outpouring of concern that the proposed regulations have generated should be interpreted as a friendly but firm reminder that the Department needs to comport with both the spirit and letter of the law's supporters.
response: We appreciated hearing from commenters who supported the requirement to disaggregate results on each indicator, and we agree that this requirement is vitally important to ensuring equity and meeting other statutory requirements related to indicators. For too long, the performance of individual subgroups was hidden within State accountability and reporting systems, and the ESSA has maintained a focus on illuminating the performance of each subgroup by requiring in section 1111(c)(4)(B) that States measure each indicator for all students and separately for each subgroup of students. Additionally, in order to identify schools with consistently underperforming subgroups of students for targeted support and improvement, the State must consider the performance of individual subgroups based on each indicator. We understand that this requirement to disaggregate results on each indicator may limit to some degree a State's selection of indicators for its statewide accountability system, but the reasons for such disaggregation are compelling, and the ESSA requires this disaggregation. Therefore, we decline to make any changes. The only exception to this requirement, as discussed previously, is that the Progress in Achieving English Language Proficiency indicator need not be disaggregated by student subgroup because it is measured for only one subgroup: The English learner subgroup.
pressure_phrases: A number of commenters opposed the requirement and recommended the Department remove or modify this provision.

title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-12451
Comment on FR Doc # 2016-12451
Tester(1)
coalition: national association of state board of education
ask: While I appreciate the Department's ongoing efforts to implement this law, I have serious concerns about the impact this particular proposed rule will have on states' efforts to craft accountability systems that meet the needs of their students
ask1: I strongly urge you to reconsider the proposed time line, so that states and districts have the time they need to implement ESSA well.
ask2: The Department proposes requiring that states assign ratings and summative scores to schools. Again, such a requirement would narrow the choices available to state and local decision-makers and lock them into a certain path, when ESSA aimed to free them from federal requirements. The Department's proposal may be a good one for some states, but it may not work for all of them. Some states may decide that a three-tier rating system may be an inappropriate way to evaluate a school's quality, and some states may decide that a single surnmative rating glosses over the varied factors that contribute to a school's success. If a state so decides, it should have the freedom to choose the method that works best for its schools.
ask3: The Department proposes specific, mandated interventions for schools that fail to test 95 percent of their students. It is certainly important to make sure that states are accounting for the performance of all of its students, but the Department's proposal too closely resembles NCLB's failed "test and punish" culture. Test scores are not the only indicator of a school's quality, and states should take the lead in holding their schools accountable when the 95 percent benchmark is met Additionally, the Department's proposed rule is troublingly silent on how these punitive measures would apply in instances where a state makes a good-faith effort to test all students but technological glitches outside of their control get in the way, as we have recently witnessed throughout the country.
response: We have revised § 200.19(d), and made conforming revisions throughout the final regulations, to allow States to: (1) Identify schools for comprehensive support and improvement no later than the beginning of the 2018-2019 school year; (2) identify schools with low-performing subgroups for targeted support and improvement that also must receive additional targeted support no later than the beginning of the 2018-2019 school year, based on data from the 2017-2018 school year, and (3) allow States to identify schools with consistently underperforming subgroups for targeted support and improvement no later than the beginning of the 2019-2020 school year. We have made also made additional clarifying edits, including renumbering and reorganizing this section, that do not change the substance of the requirements. Additionally, given revisions to the deadlines for submission of consolidated State plans, if a State chose to submit its plan in the first application window, it is possible the State may be able to begin their process for identifying schools for comprehensive and targeted support and improvement sooner than the required timeline in order to take advantage of the new multi-measure accountability systems established under the ESSA more quickly.
pressure_phrases: Some commenters also encouraged the Department to allow States, under the proposed extended implementation timelines, to maintain their lists of identified schools from the 2016-2017 school year into the 2017-2018 school year consistent with the flexibility for the 2016-2017 school year under the ESSA transition provisions.

title: Comment Submitted by Bernie G. Thompson, U.S House of Representatives, Committee on Homeland Security
ask: Do not advance proposed idea; "I write to express serious reservations about the Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) proposal to impose a disaster deductible on States seeking Public Assistance under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Reiief and Emergency Assistance Act (Stafford Act)."

title: Comment Submitted by Rep. Bennie Thompson, U.S. House of Representatives
ask: Do not advance proposed idea; "I write to express my concerns regarding the Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) proposed disaster deductible for reimbursement for the repair and replacement of public infrastructure following a disaster. Although I recognize the need to reduce Federal costs associated with disaster response and recovery activities, I oppose implementing the proposed disaster deductible as it would shift costs to the States after a disaster. Instead of limiting States' access to Federal Public Assistance funds when they are in the throes of disaster response and recovery, FEMA should pursue policies that will make disasters less costly by helping States invest in hazard mitigation activities and resilience plruming before disaster strikes. "
ask1: Revise program to ensure that costs are not shifted to states; "Although FEMA asserts that the "primary intent of the deductible concept is to incentivize greater State resilience to future disasters," 1 it appears that the primary intent ofthe deductible is to reduce Federal disaster costs by shifting the burden to States. "
ask2: Do not place so much weight on disaster risk when creating the ratio to asses each state's disaster deductible; "The proposed ratio to assess each State's disaster deductible places too much weight on a State's "disaster risk," while failing to adequately consider a State's fiscal capacity. If a State's risk of disaster accounts for 75 percent of the disaster deductible formula, the deductible has the effect of punishing disaster-prone States by driving up disaster deductibles based on the risks of natural weather events that cannot be prevented. "
ask3: Reduce the adiminstrative burden of the proposal; "In addition to the fmancial hardship the disaster deductible can have on States, the proposed credit structure can also be administratively burdensome. Though States can participate in hazard mitigation and other disaster planning activities that will help to buy down deductible amounts, the administrative cost associated with keeping track of credits will add to the overall yearly cost associated with this rule. "

title: Comment Submitted by Congress of the Unites States (IL Delegation)
org_name: Senator Richard J. Durbin-Il;Senator Tammy Duckworth-Il;Representative Rodney Davis-Il;Representative Mike Quigley-Il;Representative Daniel Lipinski-Il;Representative Cheri Bustos-Il;Representative Robin L. Kelly-Il;Representative Luis V. Gutierrez-Il;Representative Bill Foster-Il;Representative Jan Schakowsky-Il;Representative Mike Bost-Il;Representative Adam Kinzinger-Il;Representative Raja Krishnamoorthi-Il;Representative Bradley S. Schneider-Il;Representative Peter J. Roskam-Il;Representative Darin Lahood-Il;Representative Randy Hultgren-Il;Representative Danny K. Davis-Il;Representative Bobby L. Rush-Il;Representative John Shimkus-Il
ask: Redevelop proposed idea; "We are writing to express concerns about the Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) supplemental advance notice of proposed rulemaking regarding a Public Assistance deductible that would require states to meet a predetermined, annual expenditure of state emergency management funds or disaster recovery costs to qualify for FEMA Public Assistance in the event of a natural disaster. While FEMA's Public Assistance declaration review process is in need of reform, it is important to get it right. "
notes: coalition of Illinois congressmen
